definition:
A topological space $ X$ is [*connected im kleinen at a point*]{} $ x $
if every open set $ U$ containing $ x$ contains an open set $ V$
containing $ x$ such that if $ y$ is a point of $ V$, then there is a
connected subset of $ U$ containing $\{x,y\}$.\
Another way to say this is that $X$ is connected im kleinen at a point
$x$ if $x$ has a neighborhood base of connected sets (not necessarily
open).

A locally connected space is connected im kleinen at each point.

A space can be connected im kleinen at a point but not locally connected
at the point.

If a topological space is connected im kleinen at each point, then it is
locally connected.

[9]{} S. Willard, *General Topology*, Addison-Wesley, Publishing
Company, 1970. J.G. Hocking, G.S. Young, *Topology*, Dover Pubs, 1988,
republication of 1961 Addison-Wesley edition.
